required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Apnea Tolerance in Two Positions of Patients With BMI 30-40
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Apnea Tolerance in Two Positions of Patients With Body Mass Index (BMI) 30-40

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the effect of the 25° head-up position versus the 55° head-up position on tolerable apnea time (TAT) after induction of general anesthesia in patients with a body mass index (BMI) of 30-40.

study_design_info.masking_description: The person measuring and recording the study data will be blinded.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Time between start of induction of general anesthesia (SpO2 100%) to decline of SpO2 94%, up to eight minutes
primary_outcome.description: Measure of the TAT between groups to determine if the TAT is a function of the participant's position.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time between start of the tracheal intubation procedure to completion of tracheal intubation, up to 2 minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: Peripheral arterial hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SpO2) trough
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time until SpO2 decreased to 92%, up to 8 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Measure of the rebound SpO2. It is the lowest SpO2 reading reached subsequent to start of mechanical ventilation at the SpO2 value of 94% and it represents final completion of SpO2 decline.

arm_group.description: Participants will be positioned at 25° angle for procedure.
Participants will be positioned at 55° angle for procedure.

intervention.description: Participant will be positioned at 25° angle for procedure.
Participant will be positioned at 55° angle for procedure.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-III
- Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30-40
- Scheduled for an elective surgery that requires tracheal intubation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with abnormalities of the upper airway that require awake tracheal intubation
- Asthma
- Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
- Congestive heart failure
- Pregnant patients
